summary.abstract: This article in Spanish by Sandra Sáenz-López Pérez examines the medieval orb (pomo) as a royal insignia and its formal and symbolic connections to medieval cartography. The author argues that the most common type—the 'tripartite orb'—derives directly from the T-O map tradition dividing the known world into three continents (Asia, Europe, Africa), tracing its iconographic evolution from Roman imperial portraiture through medieval representations of emperors, kings, and Christ the Savior. A second cartographic type, the 'geographic orb,' is linked to 15th-century Florentine cartography—specifically the recovery of Ptolemy's Geography and the work of Henricus Martellus Germanus—and is visible in representations such as Marco d'Oggiono's Salvator Mundi and Martin Behaim's 1492 globe.
